zuul/lib/ansible.py.message: Let's add a comment here why we're setting it to 2.
Why not stick to only one worker and remove the risk entirely?

Serially installing quite some ansible versiones takes significantly longer each time the tox venv is recreated. Using two workers is an attempt to minimize both those races and the time to setup the venvs. If we then still face the race I'd suggest to separate the caches of pip so they cannot interfere with each other.

openstackclient/tests/functional/identit.message: We could also just use "self.skipTest()" without the raise. there's a testtools method for skipping tests ...

There's no "self" here in this classmethod. But even if there were, that does the same thing, which is raise the exception. And the weird thing is that the code that special cases the exception is looking for the wrong one (from unittest rather than unittest2) in py3 :(

Probably isn't. But this whole thing shouldn't be needed. There's a weird thing happening here where testtools tries to load up unittest/unittest2 but prefers the latter, so TestCase.SkipTest is resolving to the unittest2 incarnation; but for some reason when running this test suite, we end up in a code path that checks for the unittest one :(

Anyway, I used unittest.case.SkipTest because that was the exact symbol showing up in pdb and there was enough weirdness going on that I didn't want to take any chances.

os_vif/utils.py.message: Note to self: this nicely mirrors the kernel's way of setting a random MAC, ref: https://elixir.bootlin.com/linux/v5.4.8/source/include/linux/etherdevice.h#L223
it nicely mirrors because it was copied from kernel implementation :)
i have not looked at this closely yet either but this was actully something that was conserning to me. im not sure im ok with this.

i would prefer a config option but i would be ok with either.

the reason i would prefer the config item is there is a second mac prefix that is used by neutron  for dvr and we wont be able to discover it the same way.

but ill leave it to you to decide. i would guess most people will not alther the default so we could choose a prefix that does not collide and has the relevent bits set. we could also document that the local assignment bit should be set and multicast bit should be cleared in any prefix provided but skip enforcement as you said. if we wanted to enforce it we could do a check in the os_vif initialisation.

so can i make another suggestion.

im still a little uncomfortable with this being completely random but i could live with it as a defualt.

neutron has a base mac config option for it mac adresses

https://github.com/openstack/neutron/blob/9de86ddc4858ef2ae048e19c3b7ba13d185c58f5/neutron/conf/common.py#L43-L47

i would be more comfortable with this is we looked at how they generated there mac adresses and did something similar with a slight different base mac prefix so that we could not collide? what do you think?

I am ok with changing implementation to use random.getrandbits().

if we have the neutron mac prefix, to ensure we dont hit a valid neutron address we shall xor the first 3 bytes with the prefix then clear multicast bit and set local assignment bit.

if we go with config opt for os-vif ovs plugin, only the lower 3 bytes will be randomized, the upper 3 bytes shall be taken from the provided configuration option. no enforcement for multicast and local assignment bits will be performed.

yea, a more accurate statement would be "inspired" by kernel :)

basically creating a 6 byte random buffer then clearing multicast bit and setting the locally administered bit.

Config opt it is then, was not aware of other mac prefixes thanks.

only downside of having a fixed prefix is a reduced range for random mac generation.

The kernel code uses a different algorithm (this function returns a formatted string and grabs a random byte one at a time). However, barring random number weirdness, it should functionally do the same thing.

mac addresses are generated by neutron-lib, see [1],[2].
(as a side note, looking at the implementation of [2] its seems like the more you call this method its going to take longer to generate a mac which is unique but not related to our discussion)

since the base_mac neutron configuration is only available on the controller node, we could either:

1. read mac address of the VIF that's going to be unplugged and ensure first 3 bytes dont collide when generating mac (or maybe, to determine the prefix, do this for the first VIF only assuming module is loaded once).

2. define config opt e.g cleanup_mac_prefix

I personally prefer 1 as its implicit and does not require extra configurations what do you think?

[1]https://github.com/openstack/neutron-lib/blob/bcb9c90072717cd1a3db161583c9581f7d49c1ac/neutron_lib/utils/net.py#L31
[2]https://github.com/openstack/neutron-lib/blob/bcb9c90072717cd1a3db161583c9581f7d49c1ac/neutron_lib/utils/net.py#L49
if its actully copied for the kernel impelamtnion then it cant be used. that would be a gpl violation.
this is a little bit ugly but i guess its fine.

So we could impose some restrictions on the randomization
to make sure the mac addresses generated dont collide with neutron mac address range.

@Adrian: ack on VF vs representor MAC. However, a VF _might_ be rebound to a netdev (if it's a CX-3, it needs to be rebound for the whole port info thing) after unplugging.

I think it would be cleaner having the VF's always remain bound to vfio, but I'm not 100% sure all setups would function that way. No worries about trying to fix it if it's not a problem in my opinion though.

can we set the mac back to the 0 mac adress.
i seam to rememeber that that instruct the driver to reinitallise it?

what is representor vf ?
in DPDK there is only DPDK VF representor port, when its removed from OVS its deleted (am i wrong here ?).

in legacy sriov case the administrative mac of the VF is zeroed which causes the kernel driver to randomize the mac on the next driver rebind. here we are taking the same approach.

DPDK VF representor port MAC and VF MAC are the same.
(actually to my understanding, one represents the other)

please remember that VF may not be binded to networking driver so it will not have a netdevice.

should we not delete the representor vf instead.

a random mac could result in a mac conflict and break network connectivity so with out a way to prevent that i think this is a non starter.

we have had cases in the past where failing to remove a mac from a vf lead to a netwrok partation in on migration so this is a security risk in my book.

so my understanding is that the mac the kernel would set is not totally random. it would reset to the mac the vf originally had which would come from the the set of macs allocated to the network vendor.


what im concerned about is a network partition.

if the mac that is generaged conflict with a mac in use by a guest (on a flat network) or in use by a vxlan tunnel enpoint on a ovs bridge on the same physnet then it could cause a network partition.

we have had cases in the past where the vf mac was not correctly reset when we migrated a vm. as a result there was a network partition between the souce host and the dest host as the source host still had a vf with the vms mac asigned.

you are try to us a random mac to prevent that form happening here but im not sure that is correct to do.

if i am reading this code correctly what you are doing is detecting if the port is a dpdk hardware offloaded port representor, if it is seting the representor to a random mac
then deleting the interface.

didn't you say that when you delete the interface it will delete the dpdk representor created by the pmd so setting the back is to ensure the VF is updated to the random mac.

i dont think that is a safe operation given we dont ensure that mac is not in use already on the host. i think the kernel would protect form that. The kernel could not ensure it would not conflict with other hosts but given all nutron generated macs are confiend to a specifc range by default that is independent for any vendor mac range there should not be a conflict. a random mac however could conflict with neutron.

i have not looked at how you are generating it to be sure but that is why im not sure this is a good idea.

unfortunately, it is not.
setting zero mac is blocked by DPDK.

In DPDK setting zero mac is blocked.
(while Mellanox works in a bifurcated mode and VF can be managed via iproute, other vendors PMD's that are pure user-space cannot do the same)

I had an internal discussion with our DPDK team on whether or not zero mac should be allowed like in kernel.
their take was: if mac was set by the user, it should be cleaned by the user.

This PS proposes to clean mac address like its done today in kernel (randomize the mac).
That would mirror the mechanism in the kernel. I'm also in favour of that if the code exists upstream.
cleanup_base_mac

nova/virt/libvirt/driver.py.message: maybe say something like 'xxx is not supported' etc is better?

I'd rephrase the error message, because of the following.  (Maybe even add it as a NOTE.)

It is true that libvirt does not know how to detect host CPU model on AArch64, but even if it _wants_ to know, it cannot, because even the `/proc/cpuinfo` on AArch64 doesn't show anything interesting.  There are lots of vendors making different AArch64 CPUs, and they are not easily comparable.  They all differ in various ways.  (This is also confirmed by Jiri Denemark of libvirt.)

So it doesn't make sense to do CPU compatability check on AArch64.  And the AArch64 folks themselves recommend that the way to run KVM guests on AArch64 is via 'host-passthrough'.

So with that in mind, I'd suggest something like:

  "Host CPU compatibility check does not make 
   sense on AArch64; skip CPU comparison"

Further, underscores are not allowed in neither Group, Version, nor Name for kubernetes resources. I think this notation should be pretty error-proof

I guess I'll add documentation for this function. Something like

getTreeByPath <GVK> <ResourceName> <JSONPath>

GVK - Group, Version and Kind of resource to search. Use underscore ('_') as a separator. If desired resource does not  have Group, Version and/or Kind use '~G', '~V', '~K' respectively (e.g. '~G_v1_Secret')

ResourceName - Name of the resource to search

JSONPath - path to the field used as a source of data (e.g. 'spec.path.[0].to.some.data')


reference/charter.rst.message: An "election" doesn't necessarily involve a poll. If the candidates are uncontested, then they are acclaimed at the end of the nomination period with no poll needed, but that's still an "election" (in the sense that the polity elected to put forth no alternative candidates to run against them).

The problem with "no later than" for the TC election is it theoretically means that two elections could be called back-to-back in order to age out somebody the majority didn't like. To guard against this we also need to specify something like "no earlier than 6 weeks prior" to the final release date.

Alternatively, I think it's fair to assume/require that any TC member is expected to at least serve for x months and therefore be elected knowing such (I would say x=5 or more). In other words, TC seats would be elected for a term of minimum 150 days.

That way, there would be a minimum and maximum term length w/ two elections. It strengthens the constraints and avoids your scenario. It doesn't prevent someone from resigning early either.

Resignations are another thing to handle, which might lead to another set of elections?

Do you really think we need to guard against the majority doing something like this?  If this scenario happens then either someone genuinely toxic has been elected, or the comity and general assumption of good intent has completely broken down in the community.
but there is no election for such vacancy. Next para @L170 stats about such situation.
I am fine with not adding an extra info, myself. I am just proposing a different alternative to complex wording, which would still be matching expectations.

> Do you really think we need to guard against the majority doing
 > something like this?

Yes.

 > If this scenario happens then either someone
 > genuinely toxic has been elected, or the comity and general
 > assumption of good intent has completely broken down in the
 > community.

Yes, and that is exactly why we have legal documents (like this one, which is effectively incorporated into the bylaws by reference) to stop things getting to that point.

To be clear, I am RV-1 on this change if it remains as is. It's already a slight stretch to define only the formula for the length of a term using as-yet-unknown information prior to the election; it would be grossly irresponsible to allow that formula to produce results anywhere between 0 and 14 months.

I agree with ttx's suggestion that we should allow ourselves some wiggle room with respect to the time between the election and the release date, but it would be a total failure of governance to neglect to define the amount of wiggle room.


JP's concern could easily be addressed by changing " election" to "scheduled election" on line 162 to make it clear that any special elections that may occur don't reset the clock for everyone. We already use that term in the next section.
I understand your comment and the situation you are considering but I think that is rare now with the decrease in TC seats. And it if that still occurs then time to shrink it further?
Let's add this case also explicitly in charter. I agree on having the election in that case vs keep seat vacant for more than 4 weeks.

Actually, this doesn't alleviate Zane's concerns, as an election to push someone out could still happen at the beginning of a given release cycle, only 4 weeks after the previous election. Ignore me :)

I was explicitly mentioning the case of "now", in which we have no "not winning candidates" (everybody got elected and no extra candidates). In that case, I assumed an election would occur (even though it's not in the charter).

As I also said, it's a series of events which are unlikely to happen. Sorry if the context of my comment was not clear.

Not my call, but I would recommend not explicitly stating any kind of minimum. If some situation arises where extreme measures are called for, better not to have a conflict with the charter. I agree with Nate on this one.

If there is some vacancy due to any reason before the term expires, it is handled in the next section L170. There is no in-between election thing for that. Either seat will be open till next term election or filled with 'not winning candidates' in previous election.

My concern is of the same kind as Zane: What if we have to run another set of elections mid term (more than 4 weeks before next elections), because y/z had to leave their position, and let their seat vacant to a point nothing can get done? (Assuming, like we had for the latest elections, no extra candidates for TC, and therefore no one to ask to if they want to join...). For me, that series of events would justify extra election. With the current wording, it could be a problem for continuity. Though in my case, adding "regular" after staggered would be enough: extra elections would be "exceptional" in this case.

It's also a very rare case, which we can probably ignore, assuming we'll get more TC candidates than the new _smaller_ TC size.

In other words, maybe we don't need extra conditions, because likelihood of worst case happening is low :p

I am convinced on defining the duration to avoid back to back election. In addition, let's mention the vacant seat election in charter which is not there which is why I was in impressions that only scheduled election can occur. But this cycle situation open up a new area to explicitly address.

If we change to "scheduled election", could we also say that there should be only one "scheduled TC election" per cycle release? Zane, would that alleviate your concerns in a different way? Are there edge cases I'm missing with this?
typo: scheduled
Done
typo: candidate
Done

Should we try to explicitly call this out as something other than a regularly scheduled election? (In Westminster systems it's known as a by-election; in the US as a special election. Maybe one of those terms?)

Initially, I thought of calling it 'by-poll' used in India or 'special' but dropped that in case both are not well-known term for election. 

'special' sounds good ti add. done

reference/upstream-investment-opportunit.message:
I am not sure this business case section really encompass the business value for the leadership of some organization which might come across it.

IMO, the business case could be that the inconsistent RBAC could very costly -- it could lead to security issues, or role inefficiencies.
Good point, but it would be best to frame it in a way that answers the question: why should *my* company do this work rather than just benefiting from the work others do?

I should have elaborated on business cases when I originally wrote this. I missed a good one.

If you operate a deployment that relates to financial or medical information, you will benefit from consistent RBAC because you're probably subject to audits and strict regulations. Or if you sell software to financial institutions, medical facilities, or branches of government, consistent RBAC is almost always a requirement before you install OpenStack.

Some organizations can't even begin to use OpenStack because the current approach to RBAC violates regulations they need to meet.

It would be good if Keystone/RBAC folks took over this review  (or propose a new one and I'll abandon this one) so that Colleen's point is addressed and the best business case is presented.  My aim in proposing these reviews was to move the agenda and I really have no informed stake in the particulars of *this* review itself (though I've learned something and will try to help from the manila side with adjustments to align with consistent RBAC).

Can we lead with this?

There are a lot of organisations (all public clouds for a start, but also others of the kind you describe here) for whom the current default policies are entirely unsuitable, and they're all spending considerable amounts of effort every time they upgrade OpenStack in creating and verifying those policies, and they're exposed to a substantial business risk if they get it wrong. Investing in creating good defaults once will reduce the cost of every upgrade, which in turn will improve their time-to-market with features and bug fixes, all while reducing business risks.

Building influence is nice and all but it seems unlikely to keep the target audience reading until paragraph 3; this is the much more compelling point.

horizon/exceptions.py.message:
(Note for reviewers)
This might need a detail explanation.
In the original code, exc_* variables are referred. They are assigned at two places: L.294 from sys.exc_info() and L.307 if handled=True.
If handled=True, wrap is set to True and if wrap is True the logic goes to L.336 and it never reaches here.
Thus, exc_* variables used here are always from L.294 sys.exc_info().
Raising an exception using a return value from sys.exc_info() is just to re-raise an original exception, so we can convert it into "raise".

specs/train/approved/expose-auto-converg.message: when the host wasn't configured for it

Technically, from an operator's perspective, you could provide an aggregate with auto_converge=true metadata and just use flavors having an auto_converge=true spec (with a specific filter too).

Oh, you would then leak your hypervisor to your users, but then you could tell them to just use flavors having this spec.
That's what you actually want, nope ?

You could even ask users to tag their own images with a metadata key to be auto_converge=true and then some other filter would do the job.

Thanks for your review:
Yes, using flavor extra specs and image metadata is a more better way. But do we need to introduce aggregate?
I guess you mean to schedule these instance to the aggregate that supports auto converge, this may cause some hosts in the cluster to be heavily loaded. I think it is better to use flavor extra flags and image metadata to make live migration meet user expectations.
Also, could we add 'post copy' to here?
no, because it's libvirt specific. Users don't know which hypervisor is running behind compute API.

Based on https://docs.openstack.org/nova/latest/configuration/config.html#libvirt.live_migration_permit_auto_converge auto-converge only happens if post-copy is disabled or not available (but I think it's available in the minimum required libvirt version now: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/649671/), anyway, are you saying here that even if post-copy is enabled and available, if the API says auto_converge=True we'd start the live migration with auto-converge rather than do any post-copy?

Also, what would happen if the live migration is started with auto-converge and then the force complete API is called which tries to trigger post-copy? Will that blow up the live migration or just fail the post-copy request?

Thanks for your review:
1. No, according to this page, if auto_converge and post_copy are both True, then libvirt will use post_copy.

2. If libvirt uses auto converge during live migration, it means that post-copy is disabled, so it will not trigger post-copy when call force complete API.

Ack. I added the obj_set_defaults() line in create() to handle the keep-it-dirty compatibility, and left the obj_reset_changes() because any that are passed in via init would have been reset before. However, I very much don't like to have one object changing the behavior like that so if you're sure that we can drop that entirely I'm definitely happy with that.
Why can't we keep this as is? This change now makes the code more complicated to achieve the same behavior

The whole point of this change is to stop people from initializing fields during __init__ for objects that are not NovaEphemeralObject. So, we can't keep this behavior because it's the behavior we're trying to remove. PciDevice is very much a conventional row-based object, which means it needs to not inherit from ephemeral, and not default on init. I'd rather the code not just assume extra_info is set blindly, but the obj_load_attr() change is smaller than hunting out all the possible places that it does, and is also the compromise we've been steering people to for a couple years when they want this kind of behavior.
Thanks. I don't block on this.

There is no return expected. The object system expects this method to either return with the attribute set, or raise. Because they all have default values, the next line will set the default for whatever hits this load, satisfying the requirement.

ironic_python_agent/extensions/image.py.message:
so if I'm grokking this, we're kind of going in reverse. I'm reading this as your trying to look at the firmware and see what is in the efi bootloader nvram, as compared to what is on disk, but we need to identify, and potentially set what we find on disk.

So... something like
1) Mount EFI boot partition
2) Scan for bootx64.efi, likely in order of most complaint to spec to most non-compliant.

(Note, these are all linux style paths)
(Note2, all of these paths are x86_64. There is some variation for other architectures, so maybe the path to take is find all the files in the boot partition, and hunt for chunks of text in order, and maybe then verify that it is a file on disk? https://wiki.debian.org/UEFI)

Secure boot:

"<partition path>/efi/redhat/shimx64-redhat.efi"
"<partition path>/efi/redhat/shimx64.efi" <-- This would be 
"<partition path>/EFI/debian/grubx64.efi
"<partition path>/EFI/ubuntu/grubx64.efi
"<partition path>/EFI/opensuse/shim.efi
"<partition path>/EFI/opensuse/grubx64.efi

General boot... 
"<partition path>/efi/boot/bootx64.efi" <-- this file may actually be the shim, or it could be grub in unsigned ases.
"<partition path/efi/EFI/BOOT/BOOTX64.efi" <- The FS should be fat16... so case "shouldn't" matter, the difference is the extra EFI. An additional variation.

Windows boot which should likely be in the secure boot list:

"<partition path>Windows/System32/Winload.efi" <-- Actually for windows, this may be root volume content...

For arm: The format is bootaa64.efi/shimaa64.efi/grubaa64.efi.

3) Once we'e identified the the contents on the disk or partition, then we can update the efibootmgr contents.

> "eval the entire path" this would be verify if the efibootmgr has
 > an entry for the efi files we have found?

No, because we might have overriden the nvram by saying "network boot" via the bmc, which is what Richard's machine actually reports. The act of grub-install presently updates the nvram which puts the entry in.

So in a sense, the case is "The bootloader has been installed on disk" but we need to make sure there is an nvram entry.

of course, I pointed out the secure boot because my understanding was that the entire patch is rotating around that.
So we're looking a bit more than just checking the uefi, not only just looking for "this is uefi enabled", but also "we have a bootloader" no matter if secure boot or not; in this case any *.efi files in the path should be ok, but still we need to give priority to secure boot enabled bootloader, no?

author.name: Julia Kreger
author.status: On the moon! With a jetpack!

ironic_python_agent/extensions/image.py.message:
> of course, I pointed out the secure boot because my understanding
 > was that the entire patch is rotating around that.
 > So we're looking a bit more than just checking the uefi, not only
 > just looking for "this is uefi enabled", but also "we have a
 > bootloader" no matter if secure boot or not; in this case any *.efi
 > files in the path should be ok, but still we need to give priority
 > to secure boot enabled bootloader, no?

I don't think we need to. The standard practice is to put the BOOTX68.EFI file as the shim for Linux/Grub and then put in GRUBX64.EFI which the shim loads. If those files are signed, then in theory, we get secure boot for free. Presently we stomp on them effectively erasing secure boot.

1) would be:
 - mount root_partition on the path <temporary>
 - mount sysfs
 - mount efi_partition on the <path> + "boot/efi"

2) we can just try to find all files with .efi file name extension
Agree, I think we should concentrate on taking grub2-install out of the workflow, whether or not secure boot is confgured.

doc/source/cli/command-objects/access-ru.message: If these are specific to application credentials, maybe namespace them there? Since "access rule" is a pretty generic term and that might get used there, too? Or maybe even access rules concerning users and projects within keystone?

I guess before I go changing it everywhere I'd like to solicit more opinions on it. "access rule" doesn't currently collide with anything and I don't foresee it colliding with anything. Adding "user" would make it inconsistent with other resources owned by users like key pairs, credentials, and application credentials, and adding "application credential" makes it a pain to type out.
I think the latter would seem good enough, I'd just want to avoid filling up the top level namespace too much.
I think this is a fundamental enough construct that it's ok to do top level.

You want "openstack application credential access rule delete" ?

The access rule API that this interfaces with is /v3/users/{user_id}/access_rules, it's not namespaced under app creds. As far as I know this is the only thing in OpenStack so far called "access rules", we tried to pick a name that didn't conflict with other resources.

Access rules are owned by users so we could may be do "openstack user access rule delete"?
I agree this seems like a basic enough thing to be top level.

This seems quite inconsistent with pretty much every other UI that we have. In particular I'm comparing this to how security groups and -rules work.

We don't expose an API to create access rules directly. In the majority of cases we expect users to create their app creds and access rules with a single request. Allowing them to re-use old access rules was a secondary consideration.

whitebox_tempest_plugin/services/clients.message:
as noted on irc, long term i would prefer to remove this and tweak the heartbeat so that it reports the agent status more quickly.

then we can stop the agent, wait for it to be down, start it, wait for it to be up and then return. that would likely be quicker the 15 second wait and would be more accurate.

that said as a temporary workaround im ok with this for now.
